abstract_summ: We defined fever and cough as specific symptoms, and defined a prodromal phase as the presence of non-specific symptoms for at least 1 day before the onset of specific symptoms.INTERPRETATION: Although patients in our study presented with predominately mild, non-specific symptoms, infectiousness before or on the day of symptom onset was substantial.Of 617 rheumatic patients, 8 (1.3%) developed COVID-19 symptoms (1/8 hospitalisation, 8/8 complete recovery), following a consultation/procedure with an asymptomatic (7/8) or mildly-symptomatic (1/8) HCW.Transmission events were likely to have occurred presymptomatically for one case (possibly five more), at the day of symptom onset for four cases (possibly five more), and the remainder after the day of symptom onset or unknown.Case interviews were done to describe timing of onset and nature of symptoms and to identify and classify contacts as high risk (had cumulative face-to-face contact with a confirmed case for ≥15 min, direct contact with secretions or body fluids of a patient with confirmed COVID-19, or, in the case of health-care workers, had worked within 2 m of a patient with confirmed COVID-19 without personal protective equipment) or low risk (all other contacts).
title_summ: Children Infected With SARS-CoV-2 From Family ClustersA COVID-19 outbreak in a rheumatology department upon the early days of the pandemicChildren are unlikely to have been the primary source of household SARS-CoV-2 infectionsInvestigation of a COVID-19 outbreak in Germany resulting from a single travel-associated primary case: a case seriesDelivery of infection from asymptomatic carriers of COVID-19 in a familial clusterA three-generation family cluster with COVID-19 infection: Should quarantine be prolonged?A SARS-CoV-2 familial cluster infection reveals asymptomatic transmission to childrenA COVID-19 case report from asymptomatic contact: implication for contact isolation and incubation managementFirst COVID-19 infections in the Philippines: a case report
title_abstract_phrases: INTERPRETATION: Whilst SARS-CoV-2 can cause mild disease in children, the data available to date suggests that children have not played a substantive role in the intra-household transmission of SARS-CoV-2.Investigation of a COVID-19 outbreak in Germany resulting from a single travel-associated primary case: a case seriesBACKGROUND: In December, 2019, the newly identified severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) emerged in Wuhan, China, causing COVID-19, a respiratory disease presenting with fever, cough, and often pneumonia.A SARS-CoV-2 familial cluster infection reveals asymptomatic transmission to childrenInformation on SARS-CoV-2 asymptomatic infection and infectivity in children is limited.We defined fever and cough as specific symptoms, and defined a prodromal phase as the presence of non-specific symptoms for at least 1 day before the onset of specific symptoms.A COVID-19 case report from asymptomatic contact: implication for contact isolation and incubation managementBACKGROUND: As of 2 March, 2020, at least 80 151 coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases were reported in China.METHODS: A case was defined as a person with SARS-CoV-2 infection confirmed by RT-PCR.
